“Must” thinking is a cognitive distortion where we believe events must unfold exactly as we expect, and any deviation feels unjust. We tend to insist on our expectations and demands, without accounting for real-world circumstances or possibilities.

A classic example might be: “I should have gotten that job because I worked so hard for the interview.” In these scenarios, external factors—like other qualified candidates—often get overlooked.

This mindset can breed disappointment, anger, and frustration, hurting both mental health and personal relationships. It’s important to stay flexible with expectations and accept that outcomes can vary.
dialogSummary: Here, Person 1 shows a ‘must’ mindset, believing they must work non-stop to achieve career success, citing examples of other high achievers. Person 2 helps them rethink this belief, pointing out that everyone’s path to success is different, and balancing work and rest may be more effective.
dialog: I have to work every single day without days off if I want to succeed in my career.
Why do you believe that? What led you to that conclusion?
I read about how successful people got where they are—they never rested and just worked constantly.
But everyone’s unique, and there’s no one-size-fits-all path to success. Maybe you’ll do better with a healthy mix of work and rest to reach your goals.
